title: How to Figure Out Why a Computer Won't Boot

steps.title: Check the power supply.
steps.content: Check the power supply. Also make sure that your computer is firmly plugged in to its socket.

steps.title: Turn off your computer.
steps.content: Turn off your computer. Ensure that all your power leads are connected properly.

steps.title: Wait at least 10 seconds.
steps.content: Wait at least 10 seconds. This will allow your computer’s capacitors enough time to totally discharge. Waiting for a few seconds helps them shut down completely.

steps.title: Turn your computer back on.
steps.content: Turn your computer back on. Now, your computer will have had enough time to completely shut down.

steps.title: Shut down the computer again.
steps.content: Shut down the computer again.

steps.title: Reboot your computer after 2 minutes.
steps.content: Reboot your computer after 2 minutes.

steps.title: Choose booting options.
steps.content: Choose booting options. In case the screen displays the “Windows” logo and asks you to choose an option for booting, read the directions carefully and make your choice.

steps.title: Restart your system in Safe Mode.
steps.content: Restart your system in Safe Mode. Press F8 as your device reboots. This will take you to Safe Mode.

steps.title: Uninstall new software.
steps.content: Uninstall new software. Uninstall any new software or driver that you installed or updated recently. This may automatically resolve the issue.

steps.title: Turn it back on and get into BIOS.
steps.content: Turn it back on and get into BIOS. Look for the root of the issue. In case you have overclocked, set your FSB and vCore down to stock levels. Once you are done, click on “Exit and save changes”.

steps.title: Open up the computer.
steps.content: Open up the computer. Unscrew only the screws at the back, which are located on the very outer rim. Keep touching the metal part of the case, before you delve into your computer. This helps prevent electrostatic shock, which could potentially harm your system.

steps.title: Remove and reinstall components.
steps.content: Remove and reinstall components. Take out the memory card, graphics card and wires attached to the CPU (Central Processing Unit) pins. Remove the battery. This is located near the bottom of the motherboard. It is usually housed inside its own little holster, with a lever on one end. Wait a couple of minutes. Then reconnect each component.

steps.title: Plug in your computer.
steps.content: Plug in your computer. Then restart it. Perform steps 7 and 8 only if you are comfortable working with computers. Otherwise you could end up complicating matters further.

steps.title: Visit a repair shop.
steps.content: Visit a repair shop. In case you are not very comfortable working with PCs; or if all the above-mentioned steps failed; take your system to a computer repair shop. Describe the issue as best as you can and let them handle the problem.

steps.title: Check the power supply.
steps.content: Check the power supply.

steps.title: Check your laptop charger.
steps.content: Check your laptop charger. Ensure that you are using the right type of charger for your laptop. Laptops typically require 16-20V chargers. A charger with a different voltage may not offer enough current to power your laptop.

steps.title: Test it with a spare charger.
steps.content: Test it with a spare charger. This helps you ascertain that the current charger is not causing the trouble.

steps.title: Check the laptop battery power.
steps.content: Check the laptop battery power. Make sure the laptop battery has some charge in it. If it is running low on power, plug it in and power it up.

steps.title: Shut down your laptop.
steps.content: Shut down your laptop.

steps.title: Wait a couple of minutes.
steps.content: Wait a couple of minutes. Then restart it.

steps.title: Disconnect external accessories.
steps.content: Disconnect external accessories. Disconnect all external devices, including monitors, cameras and so on. This way, you can make sure that they are not preventing your laptop from booting properly.

steps.title: Verify that the display is functional.
steps.content: Verify that the display is functional. Ensure that your laptop screen display is functional. If your laptop’s power LED is working and you can hear the hard disk or fans whirring, but you cannot see an image on the screen, the actual problem could be with the display. Sometimes, the screen’s inverter failure causes the problem with the display. If this is the case, you could get the inverter replaced. Use an external monitor to test your laptop’s display. Plug-in your monitor, power up your laptop and immediately shut its lid. If this external monitor cannot connect to your device, then the issue goes beyond a damaged screen display.

steps.title: Visit a repair shop.
steps.content: Visit a repair shop. In case you are not very comfortable working with PCs; or if all the above-mentioned steps failed; take your system to a computer repair shop. Describe the issue as best as you can and let them handle the problem.

steps.title: Check the power supply.
steps.content: Check the power supply. Also ensure that you are using the correct power cord and adaptor.

steps.title: Disconnect external accessories.
steps.content: Disconnect external accessories.

steps.title: Check recently installed software/hardware.
steps.content: Check recently installed software/hardware. Make sure that you correctly installed or updated software and/or drivers in the recent past.

steps.title: Ensure that the display is functional.
steps.content: Ensure that the display is functional. If your Mac boots up, but you cannot access the display, then the problem most probably lies with the display hardware or with the screen itself.

steps.title: Run Disk Utility.
steps.content: Run Disk Utility. On Macs running OS X 10.8 Mountain Lion or later, you need to boot into OS X Recovery Mode. Power-off your Mac. If your system does not respond, hold down the Mac’s power button for a few seconds. It will automatically shut down. Hold down the Command and R keys. This will power-on the system again. Click on the Mac’s built-in hard drive of Disk Utility. Click “Verify Disk” and then wait for the system to complete the task.

steps.title: Safe Boot the Mac.
steps.content: Safe Boot the Mac. Shut down your system and start up, while holding down the Shift key. Holding down the Shift, Command and V enters both Safe Boot and Verbose Mode. This walks you through what Safe Boot is actually trying to do, at each stage.

steps.title: Reset the SMC.
steps.content: Reset the SMC. If nothing else works, you may wish to reset your Mac’s SMC (System Management Controller). Apple offers detailed instructions on how to go about this process.

steps.title: Reinstall Mac OS X.
steps.content: Reinstall Mac OS X. Boot into Recovery Mode and click to install Mavericks. Then follow the on-screen prompts to complete the process.

steps.title: Visit a repair shop.
steps.content: Visit a repair shop. In case you are not very comfortable working with PCs; or if all the above-mentioned steps failed; take your system to a computer repair shop. Describe the issue as best as you can and let them handle the problem.
